unit_learning_outcomes.description: Analyse civil and criminal procedural law in its historical, social and legal context
Explain, apply and critique the principles and stages of civil and criminal procedure
Communicate an integrated body of procedural law knowledge both orally and in writing
Apply statutory interpretation to problems of civil and criminal procedural law

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Students are expected to prepare for tutorials by attempting all questions in advance. Additional preparation will be required for the weeks each student is on-call.
Students will be expected to undertake the weekly required readings

enrolment_rules.description: (LAWS802 or LAWS8002) and (LAWS803 or LAWS8030) and (LAWS806 or LAWS8006)

assessments.description: There will be a number of low-value quizzes across semester on both civil and criminal procedure topics.
Students must contribute in class through on-call presentations and contributions across the semester

assessments.assessment_title: Timed Civil Procedure Hypothetical Case Task
assessments.description: Problem-based scenario requiring students to demonstrate professional writing skills in a number of civil procedure tasks which would be performed by lawyers in practice.

Students are required to consider procedural fairness in the context of New South Wales criminal courts. This may involve court observation. Findings are to be critically assessed drawing on literature provided in readings and independent research.

data.description: This unit examines the principles of civil and criminal procedure in New South Wales. The unit canvasses general principles of civil procedure, the nature of adversarial disputation, case management, pre-litigation issues and protocols, and pre-trial procedures of originating process, gathering of evidence for trial, class actions and the conduct and disposal of civil proceedings. Select topics in criminal procedure, such as classification of offences, police powers and bail, the conduct of criminal trials and sentencing will be covered. Themes of the unit concern procedural fairness, access to justice and the balance between efficiency and individual rights.
